_exec_summary.SummaryText:
PREVENTIION & RESPONSE POLICY
Progressive Farms uses a comprehensive environmental management system approach to integrate both accidental release prevention and emergency response requirements under the "One Plan" format.

STATIONARY SOURCE & REGULATED SUBSTANCES
Progressive Farms is a bulk potato packing shed.  Chlorine is used at the packing shed to sanitize the potato wash water, and at times, to bleach the potatoes.  A qualified vendor is responsible for the chlorine handling and water treatment apparatus.  

Anhydrous ammonia is the refrigerant used in the Hydro-cooler unit to chill the potato wash water in order to help pre-cool the potatoes before they enter the on-site cold storage facility (which itself uses a freon type-22 refrigerant).  A qualified vendor is responsible for the seasonal maintenance of the ammonia refrigeration system for the Hydro-cooler unit.

WORST CASE SCENARIO
The worst case toxic gas release scenario is considered to be a ton container of chlorine releasing its entire contents in ten minutes under specified weather conditions.  The worst case ammonia release scenario would not affect any additional or different receptors than that of the worst case chlorine release scenario.

ALTERNATIVE RELEASE SCENARIO
The alternative toxic gas release scenario is considered to be a slight leak of either chlorine or ammonia at a valve fitting with a maximum release rate of five (5) pounds per minute under typical weather conditions.

ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM
Progressive Farms has integrated the California Accidental Release Program (CalARP) requirements within a comprehensive environmental management system based on the "One Plan" format.  

FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY
Progressive Farms has not had an accidental release of a regulated substance during the past five years.

EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM
Progressive Farms uses a comprehensive environmental management system approach to integrate both accidental release prevention and emerge

ncy response requirements under the "One Plan" format.

PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY
All chlorine containers will be secured to anchored truncheons or otherwise chocked and secured while in service or storage.  The ammonia refrigeration system will be secured against unlawful access by being completely enclosed with fencing and the external loading valve locked closed.  All regulated substance storage areas will be labeled with the appropriate National Fire Protection Agency (NFPA) hazard warning placards.
